Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[A11y][Contrast]Color contrast for the focus on icons Facebook and Twitter with background is 1.658 which is less than 3:1" (#8185) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1184494
## Browser Details:
Firefox Version: 79.0 (64 bit)

## OS Details

Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise  ​

Version 2004 (OS Build 19041.450)


## Repro Steps:

    Hit the URL and login with appropriate credentials
    Tab till "Packages tab" item and press enter
    Tab till any package and press enter.
    Tab till "Share" section
    Check whether the color contrast for the background to focus on the icons "Facebook" and "Twitter" greater than or equal to 3:1

## Actual Results:

Color contrast for the focus on icons Facebook and Twitter with background is 1.658 which is less than 3:1

   
## Expected Results:
Color contrast for the focus on icons Facebook and Twitter with background is 1.658 it should be greater than or equal to 3:1
## User Impact:
Users with low vision would face difficulty to identify the elements if the non-text contrast is less than 3:1

## Notes
We don't control these icons. I don't know if we are allowed to/should change them.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Markdig version update" (#8292) at NuGet/NuGetGallery

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Cookies] Expire the AB test cookie in a year" (#8275) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We should expire any cookie in 13 months, no matter whether it's in EU or not.
We upgrade the cookie to V3, in order to handle these already dropped cookies.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add support for authenticated feeds as MSBuild properties (and pass throughs from upstream tooling)" (#10178) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently there are MSBuild properties for [`RestoreSources` and `RestoreAdditionalProjectSources`](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/%5BSpec%5D-NuGet-settings-in-MSBuild) which are used by the `restore` target.

However, these do not support authenticated feeds, which has become painful due to the increased use of same (Azure Artifacts, GitHub Packages, etc).

Feature request would include:
1. New MSBuild properties added to be able to specify the credentials for the respective sources specified by the existing two parameters (order sensitive matching?)

2. enable setting these same credentials via the upstream tooling:
- dotnet msbuild -restore --property:NEWPROP=TOKEN --property:RestoreSources=blah
- dotnet restore --api-key TOKEN1 --source blah1 --api-key TOKEN2 --source blah2
- dotnet build (same)
- same behavior for nuget.exe and msbuild.exe (I think?)

I'm not 100% sure if `RestoreSources` and `RestoreAdditionalProjectSources` themselves can be delimited (by what?), and how that interacts with the new properties being able to support multiple tokens in the same manner. And how that influences the dotnet/msbuild argument design, if any. For instance, I'm not sure if current behavior for the dotnet restore `source` parameter to support being itself a delimited string?

The original customer request came from [Twitter](https://twitter.com/Nick_Craver/status/1319289808087252997) via @NickCraver and @m0sa.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ManagePackageVersionsCentrally default behavior is opposite the spec" (#10183) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

After creating a Directory.Packages.props file, projects were not opted-in to ManagePackageVersionsCentrally by default.  The [spec](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Centrally-managing-NuGet-package-versions) currently reads:
>If a Directory.Packages.props file exists, all projects in that directory tree are automatically opted in to central package version management. 

Adding <ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>true</ManagePackageVersionsCentrally> to the project file addresses the issue, so this is low-priority (there's a perfectly viable workaround).

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): 
VS/dotnet/msbuild

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):
5.0.100-rc.2.20479.15

VS version (if appropriate):
16.9 Preview 2

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):
Win10 20H2

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. dotnet new a project (or create in VS)
2. Add a PackageReference to anything
3. Create a Directory.Packages.props file, add a PackageVersion to it; remove the version from the PackageReference
4. Build/restore

### Expected:
Project should build using the PackageVersion specified in Directory.Packages.props (ManagePackageVersionsCentrally should default to true if Directory.Packages.props exists)

### Actual:
PackageVersion is not used, and PackageReference has no lower bound specified so it uses the oldest package available.

>d:\temp\nuget\nuget.csproj : warning NU1604: Project dependency newtonsoft.json does not contain an inclusive lower b
ound. Include a lower bound in the dependency version to ensure consistent restore results.
  d:\temp\nuget\nuget.csproj : warning NU1701: Package 'Newtonsoft.Json 3.5.8' was restored using '.NETFramework,Versio
n=v4.6.1, .NETFramework,Version=v4.6.2, .NETFramework,Version=v4.7, .NETFramework,Version=v4.7.1, .NETFramework,Version
=v4.7.2, .NETFramework,Version=v4.8' instead of the project target framework 'net5.0'. This package may not be fully co
mpatible with your project.

## Other suggested things

### Sample Project

[Example.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/5431751/Example.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Test: VerifySignaturesAsync_ExpiredCertificateAndTimestampWithTooLargeRange_FailsAsync is flaky on mac and Linux" (#9763) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The VerifySignaturesAsync_ExpiredCertificateAndTimestampWithTooLargeRange_FailsAsync test is flaky on Mac only:
Error message:
```
Assert.Equal() Failure
Expected: 0
Actual: 1
```
or

```
Assert.Equal() Failure
Expected: 0
Actual: 2
```
Stack trace:
```
 at NuGet.Packaging.FuncTest.SignatureTrustAndValidityVerificationProviderTests.VerifySignaturesAsync_ExpiredCertificateAndTimestampWithTooLargeRange_FailsAsync() in /Users/runner/work/1/s/test/NuGet.Core.FuncTests/NuGet.Packaging.FuncTest/SigningTests/SignatureTrustAndValidityVerificationProviderTests.cs:line 234
--- End of stack trace from previous location ---
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Remote locals clear all button" (#10182) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Referenced dependencies not being copied to bin folder" (#10181) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2019
Version 16.7.6
Windows 10 X64
It is working using package.config management.

Hello everyone.

For testing I have created 3 supper usefull C# projects targetting .Net Framework 4.8.
ClassLibrary2.dll
ClassLibrary1.dll (References ClassLibrary2 instantiated in the constructor)
WindowsFormsApp.exe
Created a Nuget package, added the dll files on the lib\net48 folder and added ClassLibrary1 to Assembly References.
Added the Nuget package to the WindowsFormsApp project.
The Problem:
Rebuilding the project, only ClassLibrary1.dll is added to the output folder.
Both file exists in the .nuget\packages\testing.dependency\1.0.0\lib\net48 folder.
If I add the ClassLibrary1.dll reference manually to VS, it will copy both correctlly.

The only relevant log that I found on the output window was:

"C:\Users\User\.nuget\packages\testing.dependency\1.0.0\lib\net48".
1>                For SearchPath "C:\Users\User\.nuget\packages\testing.dependency\1.0.0\lib\net48".
1>                Considered "C:\Users\User\.nuget\packages\testing.dependency\1.0.0\lib\net48\ClassLibrary2.winmd", but it didn't exist.
I have already tryied everything without success.

[ProjectTest.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/5431106/ProjectTest.zip)

Thank you.
